reinforcements.similarity: Both address the mental-model-to-platform-model translation gap. The existing library element (Translate Between the Host's Mental Model and the Platform's Data Model in Real Time) prescribes accepting input in the user's native format and converting internally. The new element (Automatic Schedule-to-Nights Translation) applies the identical principle to the guest side: accept office days as input, derive stay nights automatically. Both use the same solution architecture: dual-format display with primary user-native format and secondary platform-native format.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Library evidence: Andreas thinks in monthly rent and floor levels, not nightly rates and apartment categories (andreas-call.txt, 3:02-3:16, 1:03-1:10). New evidence: Vince thinks in office days (Monday-Tuesday) and self-corrects when he realizes the platform needs booking nights (Sunday-Monday) at 6:27-6:43. The agent confirms this is a systemic pattern at 6:43-6:56. Kahneman's bat-and-ball problem (library) and Krug's 'every question mark adds to cognitive workload' (new) both predict errors when users are forced to perform format translations. This is now validated from BOTH sides of the marketplace: hosts translate monthly-to-nightly, guests translate days-to-nights. The platform must perform all translations for both user types.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address financial display hierarchy. The existing library element (Single-Sum Financial Display) prescribes showing one total in the user's native format before any breakdown. The new element (Novel Concepts Above Conventional Details in Listing Hierarchy) prescribes displaying monthly cost in the guest's schedule context ('$800/month for Sun-Mon nights') with nightly breakdown as secondary. Both arrive at the same principle from different user perspectives: the primary financial number must be in the user's mental model (monthly), not the platform's model (nightly).
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Library evidence: Andreas processes pricing as a sequential sum and says 'Got it' after computing a single total (andreas-call.txt, 3:02-3:16). New evidence: Vince asks 'how much would this cost?' -- a monthly-budget question -- and the agent can only offer a nightly rate that even the agent qualifies as uncertain (Customer call- Vince.txt, 4:38-4:58). Both Kahneman's bat-and-ball problem and Krug's 'don't make me think' principle confirm that requiring mental arithmetic produces errors and dropout. The single-sum monthly-first principle is now validated for hosts, guests (Nneka lens, prior run), and guests again (Vince lens, this run) -- three independent confirmations.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the human-to-digital trust handoff. The existing library element (Bridge Human Trust to Digital Trust Through Continuity Priming) prescribes that the platform echo the phone call's language, show the agent's identity, and feel like a continuation of the conversation. The new element (Verbal-to-Digital Feature Continuity) applies the same continuity principle to specific features: date trading, storage, and schedule scaling were explained verbally and must be self-evident when encountered digitally weeks later.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Library evidence: the Andreas call ends with human-to-human promises and no mention of the platform (andreas-call.txt, 5:27-6:11). New evidence: the Vince call introduces date trading verbally (5:25-5:39) and Vince responds with surface-level processing ('Right, right. Okay'). Krug's muddling-through principle predicts Vince will attempt to use these features based on incomplete memory. Kahneman's priming research (library) and Krug's self-evident standard (new) converge: the platform must be independently comprehensible, not dependent on recall of a verbal explanation. The combined insight: continuity priming applies not only to the overall platform identity but to each individual feature within it.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the first-impression evaluation at a critical moment. The existing library element (System 1 Trust Gate at Every Phase Transition) prescribes that the first 2 seconds of every new screen must signal continuity and pass System 1's automatic assessment. The new element (Instant Service Concept Recognition on Listing Load) prescribes that the service concept explainer must be in the initial page paint, before the user's first scan completes (under 5 seconds). Both share the principle that the initial render determines whether the user engages or abandons.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Library evidence: Kahneman's System 1 performs automatic assessment in under 2 seconds; if it flags the context as unfamiliar, the host abandons before System 2 engages. New evidence: Krug's scanning behavior means Vince formed wrong mental models (hotel, cleaning out) during his first scan because the service concept was not in the initial page state. The combined insight: the first-impression window is even more critical for novel services (where wrong models form instantly) than for conventional ones (where conventions guide comprehension). The System 1 trust gate must include a concept-communication gate for first-time visitors to novel service categories.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address satisfice-first search and proposal presentation. The existing library element (Pre-Packaged Proposal) prescribes presenting proposals as confirmation tasks, not construction tasks: lead with people, then terms, then a single confirm action. The new element (Satisfice-First Listing Discovery) prescribes the guest-side equivalent: surface the single best match prominently, proactively suggest alternatives when the first choice is unavailable, and never force the guest back to a blank search.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Library evidence: Bryant presents the tenant arrangement as a nearly-done deal (andreas-call.txt, 1:58-2:19). Kahneman's System 1/System 2 distinction: endorsing a suggestion (confirmation) is effortless, constructing a response (searching from scratch) is depleting. New evidence: Vince satisficed on the first listing he found and pivoted instantly when an alternative was suggested (3:52-4:02). Krug's satisficing principle: 'We choose the first reasonable option.' The combined insight: the satisficing principle governs both sides of the marketplace. Hosts confirm pre-packaged proposals; guests act on the first reasonable listing. Both sides should receive pre-selected best matches, not open-ended search or decision spaces.

contradictions.conflict: The existing library element (Anchor-Then-Advance) prescribes opening every screen with what the user already knows -- recognition before instruction. The new element (Service Concept Visual Explainer) prescribes placing the service concept explainer ABOVE the fold BEFORE photos and familiar listing details for first-time visitors. For a first-time guest, the service concept is NOT something they already know -- it is entirely new information. This creates a tension: the library says 'lead with what is familiar,' but the new element says 'lead with what is most important, even if it is unfamiliar.'
contradictions.evidence_comparison: The library element's evidence comes from a host who already understands the general concept of renting property (Andreas). The new element's evidence comes from a guest who has no mental model of the service at all (Vince at 1:19-1:33). For users with NO prior mental model, leading with the unfamiliar concept IS the most important action because without it, all familiar details (photos, location, amenities) are evaluated against wrong mental models. The new element has stronger evidence for first-time visitors to novel services; the library element has stronger evidence for returning users and conventional services.
contradictions.recommendation: Resolve by applying the library principle (anchor-then-advance) to returning visitors and the new principle (concept-first) to first-time visitors. The visual hierarchy should adapt based on whether the user has been to the platform before. First visit: concept above photos. Return visit: familiar anchor (their search, their location) above concept reminder.

extensions.gap_filled: Self-evident service concept communication for first-time guests at discovery and listing evaluation. No existing library element addresses the specific challenge of making a novel service category comprehensible within a single scan. Existing elements focus on trust gates and depletion management for users who already understand the service model.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence from a single lens. Vince's call provides direct evidence of total concept failure (1:19-1:33), and Krug's usability laws provide well-established theoretical backing. The gap is clear and the evidence is strong, but additional guest calls would further validate the specific solution (one-sentence concept + 3-panel visual).

extensions.gap_filled: Visible flexibility guarantees at every commitment point in the guest journey. No existing library element addresses schedule-uncertainty anxiety as a persistent emotional barrier to commitment. The existing library covers depletion-aware design and trust gates but not the specific fear of being locked into inflexible terms that characterizes hybrid workers with uncertain schedules.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. Vince raises flexibility before pricing (5:06-5:25), establishing it as a higher emotional priority than cost. This is a strong signal. However, it is a single guest call -- additional guest calls would confirm whether flexibility anxiety is universal among hybrid workers or specific to guests with employer-unconfirmed schedules.

extensions.gap_filled: Scannable card-based move-in guide for guests. No existing library element addresses the physical-digital gap at move-in or the operationalization of verbal promises (storage, home-feel) through scannable mobile-first content. The existing library focuses on pre-move-in phases (discovery through acceptance) and post-move-in management (active lease).
extensions.confidence_note: Medium confidence. The evidence for scanning behavior at move-in is well-established via Krug, and the 'feel like home' promise from the Vince call is concrete. But no actual move-in experience data exists in this lens -- the move-in phase is projected from the call, not observed directly.

extensions.gap_filled: Flexibility reassurance timed to the moment of commitment (hover/focus on commitment buttons). No existing library element addresses the temporal precision of reassurance delivery -- the principle that the right information must arrive at the exact moment of peak anxiety, not before (when it may be forgotten) or after (when it is too late).
extensions.confidence_note: Medium confidence. The principle is well-grounded in Krug's visual hierarchy and Vince's flexibility anxiety evidence. However, the specific hover-reveal interaction pattern is a design proposal that requires usability testing to validate that the timing actually reduces commitment hesitation.

extensions.gap_filled: Optimistic proposal submission with transparent status tracking. No existing library element addresses the post-submission waiting experience from the guest's perspective. The existing library's Pre-Packaged Proposal element (communicates-005) addresses the host's acceptance experience but not the guest's submission-and-wait experience. The gap is the black-box period between guest proposal and host response.
extensions.confidence_note: Medium confidence. Vince's call ends with 'I will have myself or someone get in touch with you shortly' (6:27), which creates the exact black-box scenario. Krug's muddling-through principle strongly supports transparent progress tracking. But the specific status tracker design (3-step, optimistic, with timeline) requires A/B testing to validate its impact on guest retention during the wait period.

extensions.gap_filled: Emotional design principle of making the guest feel smart rather than tested -- specifically applied to schedule input interfaces where the platform's data model diverges from the guest's mental model. No existing library element addresses the emotional dimension of format translation: the existing works-006 addresses the cognitive cost but not the emotional cost (feeling incompetent, apologizing for errors) of being forced to think in the platform's language.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. Vince apologizes ('I'm sorry') for his own translation error (6:27-6:43), providing direct evidence that the format mismatch produces negative self-assessment. Krug explicitly connects 'feeling smart' to retention (Ch.2, p.28-29). The emotional dimension is a genuine extension beyond the cognitive dimension already in the library.

new_tokens_flagged: illustration-stroke: 2px accent-green (#2d5a3d) stroke weight for line-art illustrations (looks-001) -- not in tokens.json
badge-office-day: accent text on accent-light with radius-full (looks-002) -- component-level token, not in tokens.json

badge-stay-night: ink-muted text on bg-deep with radius-full (looks-002) -- component-level token, not in tokens.json. NOTE: looks-002 itself flags that ink-muted (#8a857e) on bg-deep (#eae7e1) fails WCAG AA at ~2.3:1 and recommends ink-soft (#4a4640) instead
callout-flexibility-border: 4px solid signal-info left border (looks-003) -- component-level token, not in tokens.json
calendar-cell-active: accent-light bg with 2px accent border (looks-007) -- component-level token, not in tokens.json
calendar-cell-roommate: bg-deep bg with 1px border (looks-007) -- component-level token, not in tokens.json
calendar-cell-hover: accent-bright 2px border (looks-007) -- component-level token, not in tokens.json
badge-best-match: IBM Plex Mono 11px, accent on accent-light, radius-full (looks-006) -- component-level token, not in tokens.json
token_compliance.recommendation: The flagged tokens fall into two categories: (1) illustration-stroke is a genuinely new primitive that should be added to tokens.json if line-art illustrations become a repeating pattern across the design system. Recommend adding after a second lens confirms the illustration pattern. (2) The remaining 7 tokens are component-level compositions of existing primitives (accent, accent-light, bg-deep, border, radius-full, etc.). These should be defined in a component token layer that extends tokens.json rather than polluting the primitive token file. The WCAG failure on badge-stay-night must be resolved before implementation: use ink-soft (#4a4640) instead of ink-muted (#8a857e) for accessible contrast on bg-deep backgrounds.

arc_conflicts: feels-006 targets 'excitement' during the post-proposal wait, but feels-002 targets 'safety' at the acceptance commitment point immediately following. The emotional arc goes excitement (waiting for response) to safety (signing lease), which is a downward energy shift that could feel deflating. Recommendation: the status tracker (feels-006) should transition from excitement to anticipatory safety as the host response arrives, bridging the emotional gap rather than creating a step change.

feels-001 targets 'calm' at discovery, and feels-004 targets 'momentum' at search. The transition from calm to momentum requires an activation event. The current elements do not explicitly design for this activation -- the guest must shift from 'I understand this' (calm) to 'I want to find my place' (momentum) without an explicit emotional trigger. Recommendation: the service concept explainer (feels-001) should end with a forward-looking prompt ('Find your place near [location]') that naturally activates the momentum emotion.
emotional_arc_check.arc_assessment: The emotional arc makes sense end-to-end when read as a journey from confusion-to-calm (discovery), calm-to-momentum (search), momentum-to-comprehension (listing evaluation), comprehension-to-confidence (proposal), confidence-to-safety (acceptance), safety-to-relief (move-in), and relief-to-control (active lease). The dominant emotional thread is the progressive replacement of uncertainty with control. This aligns well with Vince's specific psychology: a polite, cautious person navigating a novel service with an uncertain work schedule. The two minor arc conflicts noted above are transition gaps, not contradictions, and can be resolved through bridging copy and interaction design without changing the target emotions.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: looks-002 flagged a WCAG AA contrast failure: ink-muted (#8a857e) on bg-deep (#eae7e1) yields approximately 2.3:1, failing the 4.5:1 minimum for normal text. The element itself recommends using ink-soft (#4a4640) instead, but this substitution changes the visual hierarchy between office-day badges and stay-night badges. Layer 3 should re-evaluate the dual-badge visual hierarchy with the corrected contrast values to confirm the hierarchy still communicates the primary-secondary relationship.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Use ink-soft (#4a4640) instead of ink-muted (#8a857e) for stay-night badge text. Re-verify that the office-day badges (accent on accent-light, ~4.5:1) still read as visually primary over the stay-night badges (ink-soft on bg-deep, ~4.8:1) given that the contrast ratios are now very similar.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: The emotional arc check identified a transition gap between feels-001 (calm at discovery) and feels-004 (momentum at search). The feels layer does not explicitly design for the activation event that transitions the guest from 'I understand this' to 'I want to find my place.' This is a missing emotional micro-moment.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Consider adding a transition emotion or activation prompt at the boundary between discovery and search. The service concept explainer's final element could serve as the emotional bridge: a forward-looking CTA ('Find your place near [location]') that converts calm comprehension into forward momentum. This is an emotional design decision, not a visual or interaction one.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: The coverage map shows zero elements for evaluation, onboarding, listing_creation, pricing, and retention phases. These are host-journey phases that are not addressed by this guest-journey run (as expected). However, this run's works-001 (Self-Evident Service Concept) and works-003 (Visible Flexibility Guarantees) both have implications for host-side listing creation: the listing page's information hierarchy directly depends on what guests need to see. A future host-side run should cross-reference this run's guest-side discovery elements to ensure listing creation tools produce pages that satisfy the guest-side visual hierarchy requirements.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: The guest journey's listing evaluation requirements (concept above photos, monthly cost before nightly rate, flexibility callout at the same prominence as pricing) should inform the host-side listing creation wizard. When the host creates a listing, the wizard should produce a page that satisfies these guest-side requirements automatically, without requiring the host to understand guest-side usability principles.
